threat_description: HNDL attack on transaction records: Adversaries capture encrypted SWIFT messaging, interbank transfers, and transaction records retained for 7+ years for future quantum decryption. Estimated $2-3.3 trillion GDP at risk from Fedwire disruption alone.
main_source: US Treasury FAQ on Financial Sector Quantum Risks; BIS Paper 158; Hudson Institute

threat_description: SWIFT messaging system compromise: Quantum-enabled forgery of SWIFT 3SKey digital signatures could authorize fraudulent payment instructions across 11,000+ connected financial institutions globally.
main_source: SWIFT CSP CSCF v2026; Digital Finance Group

threat_description: Digital signature forgery on long-term contracts: Mortgages, loan agreements, and financial instruments with multi-decade validity periods become repudiable when RSA/ECDSA signatures can be forged.
HSM backup key extraction: Master encryption keys wrapped with RSA in HSM backup archives become recoverable, exposing entire key hierarchies protecting decades of financial data.
crypto_at_risk: RSA key wrapping, ECDH key agreement
main_source: Thales Luna HSM PQC Documentation; NIST SP 800-227

threat_description: Core banking authentication bypass: Quantum compromise of RSA/ECDSA certificates enabling unauthorized access to core banking systems and mainframe environments.

PIN block DUKPT vulnerability: Triple-DES DUKPT base derivation keys protecting PIN blocks face quantum compromise; AES-256 DUKPT provides quantum-resistant alternative but millions of terminals require updates.
main_source: PCI SSC; Verifone/Bluefin AES DUKPT Implementation

threat_description: EMV offline authentication forgery: 90% of global card-present transactions use EMV with RSA as only approved asymmetric algorithm. Quantum forgery enables counterfeit card acceptance.
main_source: NIST PQC Conference 2022 EMV Research; EMVCo

threat_description: Card personalization key compromise: RSA-wrapped key injection keys for personalization bureaus become vulnerable, enabling fraudulent card production at scale.
main_source: PCI PIN Security Requirements; Card personalization standards

threat_description: Tokenization backend compromise: Payment tokenization services protecting stored credentials vulnerable through TLS certificate and HSM key compromise.
Protocol downgrade attack: Forcing fallback to quantum-vulnerable cipher suites during payment terminal TLS negotiation.
crypto_at_risk: TLS 1.2 cipher suites, RSA key exchange

threat_description: Terminal supply chain firmware attack: Quantum forgery of code signing certificates enabling malicious firmware injection into payment terminals.
HNDL on classified data: TOP SECRET information requiring 25-75+ year protection is actively harvested for future quantum decryption. Current encryption provides no protection against this threat.
main_source: NSA CNSA 2.0; NSM-10; CISA Quantum Readiness

threat_description: HSM backup key extraction for national security systems: Federal PKI root keys, military encryption keys, and NSS credentials recoverable from archived backups.
Federal PKI signature forgery: Quantum-enabled impersonation of federal systems and fraudulent certificate issuance affecting government-wide trust.
main_source: GSA Federal PKI; FPKI Policy Authority

threat_description: CAC/PIV card authentication compromise: Millions of deployed Common Access Cards and Personal Identity Verification credentials become forgeable.
main_source: GSA/Unifyia PQC PIV Experiments; NIST SP 800-78

threat_description: Nuclear command and control manipulation: NC3 systems with 50+ year lifecycles face highest-consequence quantum threat scenarios.
Protocol downgrade on classified networks: Forcing fallback to vulnerable algorithms during VPN/TLS negotiation on classified systems.
Five Eyes interoperability challenges: Cross-border PKI and encrypted communications require coordinated PQC migration across allied nations.
Defense supply chain firmware attack: Quantum forgery of firmware signing enables malicious code in military systems and weapons platforms.

HNDL on patient records: Healthcare data has lifetime sensitivity; genomic data and mental health records remain sensitive indefinitely. HIPAA mandates 6+ year retention but records persist 25+ years.
main_source: HIPAA Security Rule 2025 Updates; HHS OCR

threat_description: Connected medical device cryptographic failure: FDA recalls affected 465,000+ pacemakers; devices with 10-20 year lifecycles will operate when CRQCs arrive.
main_source: FDA Section 524B; FDA June 2025 Guidance; Nature Digital Medicine

threat_description: Drug supply chain authentication compromise: DSCSA serialization integrity vulnerable to quantum-forged verification responses enabling counterfeit drug infiltration.
Clinical trial data integrity attack: Pharmaceutical IP worth billions exposed; trial data sensitivity persists through 20+ year patent lifecycles.
Health Information Exchange protocol compromise: HL7 FHIR and other HIE protocols using TLS/OAuth vulnerable to session interception and credential theft.
main_source: HL7 FHIR Security; ONC Cures Act

threat_description: Healthcare HSM backup key extraction: Master keys protecting EHR databases and medical imaging archives recoverable from backups.
main_source: HIPAA Security Rule; NIST Healthcare Cybersecurity

threat_description: HNDL on subscriber identity data: Ki and OPc keys protecting subscriber authentication for 10-15 year SIM lifetimes are immediate HNDL targets. SUCI uses vulnerable ECIES.
5G network function authentication compromise: OAuth 2.0/TLS certificates authenticating NRF, AMF, SMF, UPF network functions use vulnerable RSA/ECDSA.
eSIM remote provisioning key extraction: 9 billion projected eSIM devices by 2030 vulnerable through ECDH SCP11 protocol compromise.
SS7/Diameter signaling security: Core network signaling protected by IPsec/IKEv2 vulnerable to quantum key recovery.
Network equipment certificate forgery: Base station and core network equipment certificates enabling unauthorized network element deployment.
Call Detail Record retrospective decryption: CDRs retained for legal compliance (2-7 years) vulnerable to future decryption exposing metadata and content.
main_source: ETSI LI standards; National data retention laws

threat_description: AWS KMS/CloudHSM key hierarchy compromise: Customer Master Keys protected by RSA/ECC key wrapping become recoverable from service logs and backups.
main_source: AWS KMS PQC Documentation; AWS-LC FIPS

threat_description: Azure Key Vault key exposure: Multi-tenant Key Vault and single-tenant Managed HSM using RSA for BYOK key transport vulnerable to quantum extraction.
Google Cloud KMS signature forgery: ECDSA signing keys enabling unauthorized operations and fraudulent attestations.
Multi-tenant isolation breach via key derivation: Shared key derivation functions potentially exposing cross-tenant cryptographic material.
BYOK key import interception: RSA-OAEP wrapped customer keys captured during import vulnerable to future decryption.
Cloud CA root key compromise: Root certificate authorities for cloud services enabling wholesale certificate forgery.
Secrets management exposure: HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, and similar services using envelope encryption vulnerable.
Cloud HSM backup vulnerability: HSM-as-a-Service backup archives containing RSA-wrapped keys.
HNDL on long-lived root CA keys: Root certificates with 20+ year validity periods represent permanently exposed attack surface. Compromise invalidates entire hierarchies.
main_source: CA/Browser Forum; Mozilla Root Store Policy

threat_description: Code signing certificate forgery: Software signed today remains in production 10-20+ years. Quantum forgery enables supply chain attacks at scale.
TLS key exchange vulnerability: 91.4% of top 1M websites not supporting hybrid PQC; all captured TLS sessions become retrospectively decryptable.
CRL/OCSP response forgery: Quantum-forged revocation responses enabling use of revoked certificates.
Certificate Transparency log forgery: SCT signatures becoming forgeable undermining transparency ecosystem.
Timestamping authority compromise: Long-term validation chains for archived documents invalidated by TSA key compromise.
S/MIME email encryption compromise: Archived encrypted emails recoverable; email signatures forgeable.
CA HSM backup key extraction: Root and intermediate CA private keys in HSM backups becoming recoverable.
HNDL on V2X communications: Vehicle lifecycles span 15-20+ years; SCMS uses ECC via IEEE 1609.2. All captured V2V/V2I data becomes decryptable.
OTA update and secure boot forgery: UNECE R156 mandates secure software updates; quantum signature forgery enables malicious firmware injection across vehicle fleets.
SCMS certificate infrastructure collapse: Millions of vehicles simultaneously affected by root CA compromise unlike individual vehicle attacks.
main_source: USDOT SCMS; Camp et al. qSCMS Research

threat_description: ECU and in-vehicle network compromise: SecOC authentication using AES-CMAC with ECC key establishment vulnerable to key extraction.
Telematics and connected services key extraction: TLS certificates and session keys for connected services vulnerable to retrospective decryption.
Supply chain code signing compromise: Tier-1 and Tier-2 supplier code signing enabling malicious components throughout automotive supply chain.
Keyless entry system compromise: Relay attacks combined with cryptographic weakness of AES-128 and ECC-based systems.
Protocol downgrade during hybrid transition: Forcing vehicles to use quantum-vulnerable protocols during transition period.
HNDL on grid operations data: Grid operational data has 20-40 year strategic value. CISA identifies as high-priority National Critical Function vulnerability.
main_source: CISA Post-Quantum OT Guidance; RAND; ReliabilityFirst

threat_description: Utility HSM backup key extraction: Master keys for SCADA encryption and grid control authentication recoverable from archived backups.
IEC 61850 GOOSE message signature forgery: Real-time protection system commands with sub-4ms requirements; forged commands could cause cascading grid failures.
AMI smart meter authentication compromise: IEEE 2030.5 using ECDSA/ECDH for millions of deployed meters with 15-20 year lifecycles.
Nuclear facility control system manipulation: Highest-consequence targets with 40-60 year equipment lifecycles. NRC 10 CFR 73.54 high assurance requirements.
Supply chain attack on embedded HSMs: Grid equipment with embedded security modules receiving compromised firmware updates.
Protocol downgrade on utility networks: Forcing ICS/SCADA systems to fall back to vulnerable encryption during transitions.
Real-time cryptographic performance constraints: PQC algorithm latency potentially incompatible with real-time grid protection requirements.
main_source: Grid timing research; PQC performance studies

threat_description: HNDL on SATCOM and flight data: Satellites have 10-20 year lifespans and cannot be physically upgraded. Swiss Armed Forces explicitly warn about SATCOM HNDL threat.
main_source: Swiss Armed Forces Command; ESA; CCSDS

threat_description: Aircraft lifecycle vs quantum timeline mismatch: Aircraft certified today with 20-40+ year operational lifecycles will operate when CRQCs arrive.
Air traffic management system compromise: NextGen (US) and SESAR (EU) representing $37B investment using vulnerable authentication. 131% rise in aviation cyberattacks 2022-2023.
GNSS/GPS authentication spoofing: Quantum-enabled bypass of cryptographic GPS authentication enabling aircraft position manipulation.
Satellite command and control hijacking: Satellites using RSA/ECC may be disabled or hijacked by quantum-capable adversary.
Avionics certificate forgery: Aircraft identity and maintenance certificates enabling impersonation and fraudulent airworthiness.
Aviation crypto agility challenges: DO-326A notes post-facto certification changes are costly or ineffective. Need designed-in agility.
Inter-satellite link vulnerability: Optical and RF ISL key establishment vulnerable to quantum attack.
HNDL on OT/SCADA communications: CISA explicitly warns critical infrastructure. Captured control logic, network topology, and credentials enable future physical attacks.
PLC firmware signing forgery: Replicating Stuxnet-style attacks through forged firmware causing equipment damage, production sabotage, or safety failures.
Industrial PKI certificate compromise: Factory automation, robotics, and process control relying on certificate authentication.
OPC UA protocol compromise: Widely deployed industrial protocol using RSA/ECDH/ECDSA vulnerable across manufacturing sector.
pqc_replacement: Hybrid OPC UA, PQC security policies

threat_description: VPN and remote access compromise: Industrial VPNs protecting remote maintenance and monitoring sessions.
Device attestation failure: Industrial IoT device identity and integrity attestation becoming forgeable.
Safety Instrumented System manipulation: Direct life-safety implications from compromised SIS authentication. IEC 61511/61508 functional safety depends on security.
Crypto agility constraints in legacy OT: 15-30 year equipment lifecycles with limited upgrade capability.
E-commerce TLS certificate compromise: All captured TLS sessions exposing payment card data, PII, and session credentials. Only 8.6% of top 1M sites support hybrid PQC.
P2PE decryption key exposure: Point-to-point encryption RSA-wrapped decryption keys at payment processors becoming recoverable.
Gift card and loyalty system compromise: Legacy cryptography protecting stored value and loyalty programs.
Payment gateway API authentication bypass: OAuth/JWT tokens using RSA/ECDSA signatures becoming forgeable.
Cryptographic agility failure in retail systems: Inability to migrate legacy POS and payment systems to PQC.
HNDL on content encryption keys: Content protection must remain secure for 5-20+ year commercial lifetime. MovieLabs ECP requires state-of-art cryptography.
DRM HSM backup key extraction: Master keys protecting entire studio content libraries worth billions recoverable from backups.
Content license signature forgery: DRM license servers using RSA/ECDSA enabling unauthorized content access.
Conditional Access System key compromise: DVB-CSA with 48-64 bit security already marginal; ECM encryption vulnerable.
Content manipulation and unauthorized distribution: Decrypted content enabling mass piracy and modification.
DRM supply chain TEE/OEMCrypto attack: Trusted Execution Environment and OEMCrypto implementations with limited crypto agility.
Protocol downgrade during content acquisition: Forcing use of weaker cryptography during license acquisition.
Crypto agility challenges for embedded devices: Set-top boxes and smart TVs with 7-10 year lifecycles and limited update capability.
Long-term document signature validity collapse: Legal documents require 50-100+ year validity. Property deeds and constitutional documents lose legal standing when signatures forgeable.
QTSP root key compromise: Qualified Trust Service Providers issue certificates with legal equivalence to handwritten signatures under eIDAS. Root compromise invalidates entire ecosystem.
Timestamping service retroactive forgery: PAdES-B-LTA long-term validation chains undermined. Forged timestamps enable backdating documents and creating false evidence.
Court electronic evidence repudiation: Defense attorneys can challenge digitally signed evidence as potentially forged, introducing reasonable doubt.
Land registry and property record tampering: Foundational property records requiring perpetual validity vulnerable to signature forgery.
Remote Online Notarization identity fraud: Notary certificates across 47 US states becoming forgeable.
EUDI Wallet cryptographic compromise: EU Digital Identity Wallet (2026 deployment) depends on current PKI. WSCD (wallet secure cryptographic device) keys vulnerable.
Legacy document management system agility: Enterprise DMS with embedded cryptography and limited upgrade paths.
Bitcoin ECDSA transaction hijacking: ~$718B in quantum-vulnerable addresses with exposed public keys. Early P2PK addresses including Satoshi's ~1.1M BTC permanently vulnerable.
main_source: Federal Reserve HNDL Paper; Royal Society

threat_description: Ethereum account compromise: All accounts that have transacted have exposed public keys. Vitalik estimates 20% probability of cryptographic compromise before 2030. BLS12-381 also vulnerable.
Smart contract signature dependency: DeFi protocols, DAOs, and NFT marketplaces using ecrecover. Immutable contracts cannot be upgraded without governance mechanisms.
Cryptocurrency custody HSM compromise: Institutional custody managing billions in assets. $1.5B ByBit hack (2025) demonstrates active targeting.
MPC threshold signature vulnerability: Threshold ECDSA schemes for custody and key management becoming insecure.
Hardware wallet private key extraction: Ledger, Trezor using secp256k1 with limited crypto agility.
Blockchain immutability with vulnerable crypto: Historical transaction signatures permanently embedded and becoming forgeable.
Multi-signature wallet compromise: 2-of-3, 3-of-5 and other multi-sig schemes using ECDSA becoming bypassable.
